titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Vladimir Konstantinovich Bukovskiĭ papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Lyalya Kharitonova and Lora Soroka

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-05-07T10:47-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: Data cleanup via script: removed leading and trailing spaces in the container summary; removed tags from languageOfFindingAid; added catkey; remove comma before the closing title tag; updated Preferred Citation; updated Accruals statement
Collection processed by Lyalya Kharitonova and Lora Soroka

physdesc.extent: 52 manuscript boxes, 4 card file boxes, 1 oversize box

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, notes, reports, Soviet government documents, printed matter, and photographs relating to civil liberties in the Soviet Union, post-Soviet Russia and elsewhere, political conditions in post-Soviet Russia, and promotion of international democracy.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research; materials must be requested at least two business days in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Vladimir Konstantinovich Bukovskiĭ papers, [Box no., Folder no. or title], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2017.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at https://searchworks.stanford.edu. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The papers of Vladimir Konstantinovich Bukovskiĭ (Bukovsky) document his activities from 1983 to 2004 and include biographical material; correspondence; writings by Bukovskiĭ, among them his conference papers; materials concerning publication of his books with related correspondence; and photographs depicting Bukovskii with other dissidents, political figures, family, and friends.

The correspondence is mostly legal, relating to Bukovskiĭ's legal cases and in defense of other human rights activists (not only Russian/Soviet), and includes letters from Margaret Thatcher, Winston Churchill, Zbigniew Brzezinski, and others, and Bukovskii's letters to Boris Yeltsin.

The International Human Rights Organizations File document Bukovskiĭ's involvement in various human rights organizations concerned with the treatment of dissidents. It includes materials from various organizations, such as Resistance International, National Endowment for Democracy, Center for Democracy, Freedom of Communication, Andrei Sakharov Institute, and Komitet soldatskikh materei (Committee of Soldiers' Mothers). The materials reflect the advocacy in defense and educational work by these groups, including statements and letters supporting dissident movements.

In 1992, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, President Yeltsin's government invited Bukovskiĭ to serve as an expert witness at the trial of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (CPSU) before the Constitutional Court. Russia's communists were suing Yeltsin for banning their Party and confiscating its property. To prepare his testimony, Bukovskiĭ was granted access to the documents from the CPSU Central Committee archives. He managed to scan many documents (some with high security clearance) secretly, including KGB reports to the Central Committee. The copies were then smuggled to the West and now they are available online at http://www.bukovsky-archives.net/. A number of documents were extensively quoted and cited in Bukovskiĭ's Judgment in Moscow. The collection also includes copies of these archival materials.

chronitem.event: Born, Belebey, Bashkir ASSR, Soviet Union.
Entered Moscow University to study biology.
Wrote his critical notes on the Communist Youth League (Komsomol) and was expelled from the university.
Arrested, charged with "anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda," and sent for treatment at the Special Psychiatric Hospital in Leningrad.
Helped to organize a demonstration on Pushkin Square in central Moscow to protest against the trial of the writers Andrei Sinyavsky and Yuli Daniel (Glasnost rally).
Arrested, charged with organizing the demonstration, and kept in various psychiatric hospitals.
Advocated for the right to organize demonstrations and other public protests, arrested, and sentenced to three years in an "ordinary regime" corrective-labor camp.
Managed to smuggle to the West over 150 pages documenting abuse of political prisoners in psychiatric institutions in the Soviet Union.

Accused of slandering Soviet psychiatry, contacts with foreign journalists, and the possession and distribution of Samizdat. Sentenced to two years in prison, five in a labor camp, and five more in internal exile.

Deported from the USSR and exchanged by the Soviet government for the imprisoned general secretary of the Communist Party of Chile, Luis Corvalán, at Zürich airport. Settled in Great Britain, Cambridge.
Gained a master's degree in Biology at Cambridge University.
Author, To Build a Castle: My Life as a Dissenter.
Co-founded Resistance International, along with Cuban dissident Armando Valladaresand, and was later elected a president of the organization.
Resistance International expanded into the American Foundation for Resistance International.
Author, To Choose Freedom
Visited Moscow for the first time since his deportation fifteen years prior. His Soviet-era convictions were annulled by a decree of the RSFSR Supreme Court and his Russian citizenship was restored.
Nominated aa a candidate for elections of Mayor of Moscow.
Author, Judgment in Moscow: Soviet Crimes and Western Hypocrisy
Director of the Gratitude Fund.

eventgrp.event: Elected President of the Comitatus pro Libertatibus – Comitati per le Libertà – Freedom Committees in Florence.
Received the Truman-Reagan Medal of Freedom.

chronitem.event: Co-founded the Committee 2008 for free and fair presidential elections in 2008, with Garry Kasparov, Boris Nemtsov, Vladimir V. Kara-Murza, and others.
Accused Vladimir Putin of the assassination of Aleksander Litvinenko.
Officially nominated to run for president in the 2008 Russian presidential election.
Joined the council of the new Solidarnost' coalition.
Author, Putin's Secret Empire: Will There Be a "Palace Coup"?
Accused Vladimir Putin of the assassination Boris Nemtsov.

eventgrp.event: Member of the international advisory council for the Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation
Member of the International Council of the Human Rights Foundation
Senior Fellow at the Cato Institute in Washington, D.C.
